title: Domain 3.5: Given a scenario, install or replace the appropriate power supply.
content:
âš¡ Input Voltage

Refers to voltage from the wall outlet.

  • 110â€“120V: North America
  • 220â€“240V: Europe and many other regions

Some PSUs have manual switches; others auto-adjust.

ğŸ§  Tip: Plugging 220V into a 110V-only PSU can destroy your system.

ğŸ”‹ Output Voltages

PSUs deliver multiple voltages for different components:

  • 3.3V / 5V: RAM, logic chips
  • 12V: CPU, GPU, fans, drives

ğŸ§  Tip: 12V rails are critical for high-performance hardware.

ğŸ”Œ 20-pin to 24-pin Adapter

Used when connecting older 20-pin power supplies to modern 24-pin motherboards.

ğŸ§  Tip: Use adapters only if your PSU lacks a native 24-pin connector.

ğŸ§¯ Redundant Power Supply

Servers use 2+ PSUs for high availability. If one fails, the other takes over.

ğŸ§  Tip: Common in rack-mounted systems for 24/7 uptime.

ğŸ›ï¸ Modular Power Supply

  • Modular: All cables detachable
  • Semi-modular: Some fixed cables
  • Non-modular: All cables permanently attached

ğŸ§  Tip: Modular = cleaner builds, easier cable management.

ğŸ”¢ Wattage Rating

Total power capacity of the PSU (e.g., 500W, 750W).

ğŸ§  Tip: Leave headroom for future upgrades â€” donâ€™t max out your PSU!
